PLAY.TITLE: The First Part of Henry the Fourth

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the King, Lord Iohn of Lancaster, Earle of Westmerland, with others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſhaken as we are, ſo wan with care,
Finde we a time for frighted Peace to pant,
And breath ſhortwinded accents of new broils
To be commenc’d in Stronds a-farre remote:
No more the thirsty entrance of this Soile,
Shall daube her lippes with her owne childrens blood:
No more ſhall trenching Warre channell her fields,
Nor bruise her Flowrets with the Armed hoofes
Of hostile paces. Those opposed eyes,
Which like the Meteors of a troubled Heauen,
All of one Nature, of one Substance bred,
Did lately meete in the intestine ſhocke,
And furious cloze of ciuill Butchery,
Shall now in mutuall well-beseeming rankes
March all one way, and be no more oppos’d
Against Acquaintance, Kindred, and Allies.
The edge of Warre, like an ill-sheathed knife,
No more ſhall cut his Master. Therefore Friends,
As farre as to the Sepulcher of Christ,
Whose Souldier now vnder whose bleſſed Croſſe
We are impreſſed and ingag’d to fight,
Forthwith a power of English ſhall we leuie,
Whose armes were moulded in their Mothers wombe,
To chace these Pagans in those holy Fields,
Ouer whose Acres walk’d those bleſſed feete
Which fourteene hundred yeares ago were nail’d
For our aduantage on the bitter Croſſe.
But this our purpose is a tweluemonth old,
And bootleſſe ‘tis to tell you we will go:
Therefore we meete not now. Then let me heare
Of you my gentle Cousin Westmerland,
What yesternight our Councell did decree,
In forwarding this deere expedience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West.
SPEECH.LINE: My Liege: This haste was hot in question,
And many limits of the Charge ſet downe
But yesternight: when all athwart there came
A Post from Wales, loaden with heauy Newes;
Whose worst was, That the Noble Mortimer,
Leading the men of Herefordshire to fight
Against the irregular and wilde Glendower,
Was by the rude hands of that Welshman taken,
And a thousand of his people butchered:
Vpon whose dead corpes there was ſuch misuse,
Such beastly, ſhameleſſe transformation,
By those Welshwomen done, as may not be
(Without much ſhame) re-told or ſpoken of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſeemes then, that the tidings of this broile,
Brake off our busineſſe for the Holy land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West.
SPEECH.LINE: This matcht with other like, my gracious Lord,
Farre more vneuen and vnwelcome Newes
Came from the North, and thus it did report:
On Holy-roode day, the gallant Hotspurre there,
Young Harry Percy, and braue Archibald,
That euer-valiant and approoued Scot,
At Holmeden met, where they did ſpend
A ſad and bloody houre:
As by discharge of their Artillerie,
And ſhape of likely-hood the newes was told:
For he that brought them, in the very heate
And pride of their contention, did take horse,
Vncertaine of the iſſue any way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is a deere and true industrious friend,
Sir Walter Blunt, new lighted from his Horse,
Strain’d with the variation of each ſoyle,
Betwixt that Holmedon, and this Seat of ours:
And he hath brought vs ſmooth and welcome newes.
The Earle of Dowglas is discomfited,
Ten thousand bold Scots, two and twenty Knights
Balk’d in their owne blood did Sir Walter ſee
On Holmedons Plaines. Of Prisoners, Hotspurre tooke
Mordake Earle of Fife, and eldest ſonne
To beaten Dowglas, and the Earle of Atholl,
Of Murry, Angus, and Menteith.
And is not this an honourable ſpoyle?
A gallant prize? Ha Cosin, is it not? Infaith it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West.
SPEECH.LINE: A Conquest for a Prince to boast of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, there thou mak'st me ſad, & mak'st me ſin,
In enuy, that my Lord Northumberland
Should be the Father of ſo blest a Sonne:
A Sonne, who is the Theame of Honors tongue;
Among'st a Groue, the very ſtraightest Plant,
Who is ſweet Fortunes Minion, and her Pride:
Whil'st I by looking on the praise of him,
See Ryot and Dishonor ſtaine the brow
Of my yong Harry. O that it could be prou’d,
That ſome Night-tripping-Faiery, had exchang’d
In Cradle-clothes, our Children where they lay,
And call’d mine Percy, his Plantagenet:
Then would I haue his Harry, and he mine:
But let him from my thoughts. What thinke you Coze
Of this young Percies pride? The Prisoners
Which he in this aduenture hath ſurpriz’d,
To his owne vse he keepes, and ſends me word
I ſhall haue none but Mordake Earle of Fife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West.
SPEECH.LINE: This is his Vnckles teaching. This is Worcester
Maleuolent to you in all Aspects:
Which makes him prune himselfe, and bristle vp
The crest of Youth against your Dignity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: But I haue ſent for him to anſwer this:
And for this cause a-while we must neglect
Our holy purpose to Ierusalem.
Cosin, on Wednesday next, our Councell we will hold
At Windsor, and ſo informe the Lords:
But come your ſelfe with ſpeed to vs againe,
For more is to be ſaide, and to be done,
Then out of anger can be vttered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West.
SPEECH.LINE: I will my Liege.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Henry Prince of Wales, Sir Iohn Fal-staffe, and Pointz.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Hal, what time of day is it Lad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art ſo fat-witted with drinking of olde Sacke, and vnbuttoning thee after Supper, and ſleeping vpon Benches in the afternoone, that thou hast forgotten to demand that truely, which thou wouldest truly know. What a diuell hast thou to do with the time of the day? vnleſſe houres were cups of Sacke, and minutes Capons, and clockes the tongues of Bawdes, and dialls the ſignes of Leaping-houses, and the bleſſed Sunne himselfe a faire hot Wench in Flame-coloured Taffata; I ſee no reason, why thou ſhouldest bee ſo ſuperfluous, to demaund the time of the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed you come neere me now Hal, for we that take Purses, go by the Moone and ſeuen Starres, and not by Phœbus hee, that wand'ring Knight ſo faire. And I prythee ſweet Wagge, when thou art King, as God ſaue thy Grace, Maiesty I ſhould ſay, for Grace thou wilte haue none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: What, none?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: No, not ſo much as will ſerue to be Prologue to an Egge and Butter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, how then? Come roundly, roundly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry then, ſweet Wagge, when thou art King, let not vs that are Squires of the Nights bodie, bee call’d Theeues of the Dayes beautie. Let vs be Dianaes Forre-sters, Gentlemen of the Shade, Minions of the Moone; and let men ſay, we be men of good Gouernment, being gouerned as the Sea, by our noble and chast mistris the Moone, vnder whose countenance we ſteale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſay'st well, and it holds well too: for the fortune of vs that are the Moones men, doeth ebbe and flow like the Sea, beeing gouerned as the Sea is, by the Moone: as for proofe. Now a Purse of Gold mo’t reso-lutely ſnatch’d on Monday night, and mo’t diſſolutely ſpent on Tuesday Morning; got with ſwearing, Lay by: and ſpent with crying, Bring in: now, in as low an ebbe as the foot of the Ladder, and by and by in as high a flow as the ridge of the Gallowes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſay'st true Lad: and is not my Hosteſſe of the Tauerne a mo’t ſweet Wench?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: As is the hony, my old Lad of the Castle: and is not a Buffe Ierkin a mo’t ſweet robe of durance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: How now? how now mad Wagge? What in thy quips and thy quiddities? What a plague haue I to doe with a Buffe-Ierkin?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what a poxe haue I to doe with my Ho-steſſe of the Tauerne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, thou hast call’d her to a reck'ning many a time and oft.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Did I euer call for thee to pay thy part?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Ile giue thee thy due, thou hast paid al there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea and elsewhere, ſo farre as my Coine would ſtretch, and where it would not, I haue vs’d my credit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, and ſo vs’d it, that were it heere apparant, that thou art Heire apparant. But I prythee ſweet Wag, ſhall there be Gallowes ſtanding in England when thou art King? and resolution thus fobb’d as it is, with the ru-stie curbe of old Father Anticke the Law? Doe not thou when thou art a King, hang a Theefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: No, thou ſhalt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I? O rare! Ile be a braue Iudge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou iudgest false already. I meane, thou ſhalt haue the hanging of the Theeues, and ſo become a rare Hangman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well Hal, well: and in ſome ſort it iumpes with my humour, as well as waiting in the Court, I can tell you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: For obtaining of ſuites?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, for obtaining of ſuites, whereof the Hang-man hath no leane Wardrobe. I am as Melancholly as a Gyb-Cat, or a lugg’d Beare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Or an old Lyon, or a Louers Lute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, or the Drone of a Lincolnshire Bagpipe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay'st thou to a Hare, or the Melancholly of Moore Ditch?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast the mo’t vnsauoury ſmiles, and art in-deed the mo’t comparatiue rascallest ſweet yong Prince. But Hal, I prythee trouble me no more with vanity, I wold thou and I knew, where a Commodity of good names were to be bought: an olde Lord of the Councell rated me the other day in the ſtreet about you ſir; but I mark’d him not, and yet hee talk’d very wisely, but I regarded him not, and yet he talkt wisely, and in the ſtreet too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou didst well: for no man regards it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: O, thou hast damnable iteration, and art indeede able to corrupt a Saint. Thou hast done much harme vn-to me Hall, God forgiue thee for it. Before I knew thee Hal, I knew nothing: and now I am (if a man ſhold ſpeake truly) little better then one of the wicked. I must giue o-uer this life, and I will giue it ouer: and I do not, I am a Villaine. Ile be damn’d for neuer a Kings ſonne in Chri-stendome. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Where ſhall we take a purse to morrow, Iacke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Where thou wilt Lad, Ile make one: and I doe not, call me Villaine, and baffle me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee a good amendment of life in thee: From
Praying, to Purse-taking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Hal, ‘tis my Vocation Hal: ‘Tis no ſin for a man to labour in his Vocation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pointz.
SPEECH.LINE: Now ſhall wee know if Gads hill haue ſet a Watch. O, if men were to be ſaued by merit, what hole in Hell were hot enough for him? This is the mo’t omni-potent Villaine, that euer cryed, Stand, to a true man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow Ned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poines.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow ſweet Hal. What ſaies Mon-sieur remorse? What ſayes Sir Iohn Sacke and Sugar: Iacke? How agrees the Diuell and thee about thy Soule, that thou ſoldest him on Good-Friday last, for a Cup of Madera, and a cold Capons legge?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn ſtands to his word, the diuel ſhall haue his bargaine, for he was neuer yet a Breaker of Prouerbs: He will giue the diuell his due.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Then art thou damn’d for keeping thy word with the diuell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Else he had damn’d cozening the diuell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poy.
SPEECH.LINE: But my Lads, my Lads, to morrow morning, by foure a clocke early at Gads hill, there are Pilgrimes go-ing to Canterbury with rich Offerings, and Traders ri-ding to London with fat Purses. I haue vizards for you all; you haue horses for your ſelues: Gads-hill lyes to night in Rochester, I haue bespoke Supper to morrow in Eastcheape; we may doe it as ſecure as ſleepe: if you will go, I will ſtuffe your Purses full of Crownes: if you will not, tarry at home and be hang’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare ye Yedward, if I tarry at home and go not,
Ile hang you for going.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poy.
SPEECH.LINE: You will chops.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Hal, wilt thou make one?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Who, I rob? I a Theefe? Not I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: There's neither honesty, manhood, nor good fel-lowship in thee, nor thou cam'st not of the blood-royall, if thou dar'st not ſtand for ten ſhillings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Well then, once in my dayes Ile be a mad-cap.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, that’s well ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, come what will, Ile tarry at home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile be a Traitor then, when thou art King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: I care not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poyn.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn, I prythee leaue the Prince & me alone, I will lay him downe ſuch reasons for this aduenture, that he ſhall go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, maist thou haue the Spirit of perswasion; and he the eares of profiting, that what thou ſpeakest, may moue; and what he heares may be beleeued, that the true Prince, may (for recreation ſake) proue a false theefe; for the poore abuses of the time, want countenance. Far-well, you ſhall finde me in Eastcheape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Farwell the latter Spring. Farewell Alhollown
Summer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poy.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, my good ſweet Hony Lord, ride with vs to morrow. I haue a iest to execute, that I cannot man-nage alone. Falstaffe, Haruey, Roſſill, and Gads-hill, ſhall robbe those men that wee haue already way-layde, your ſelfe and I, wil not be there: and when they haue the boo-ty, if you and I do not rob them, cut this head from my ſhoulders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: But how ſhal we part with them in ſetting forth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poyn.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, we wil ſet forth before or after them, and appoint them a place of meeting, wherin it is at our plea-sure to faile; and then will they aduenture vppon the ex-ploit themselues, which they ſhall haue no ſooner atchie-ued, but wee'l ſet vpon them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but tis like that they will know vs by our horses, by our habits, and by euery other appointment to be our ſelues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poy.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut our horses they ſhall not ſee, Ile tye them in the wood, our vizards wee will change after wee leaue them: and ſirrah, I haue Cases of Buckram for the nonce, to immaske our noted outward garments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: But I doubt they will be too hard for vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, for two of them, I know them to bee as true bred Cowards as euer turn’d backe: and for the third if he fight longer then he ſees reason, Ile forswear Armes. The vertue of this Iest will be, the incomprehensible lyes that this fat Rogue will tell vs, when we meete at Supper: how thirty at least he fought with, what Wardes, what blowes, what extremities he endured; and in the reproofe of this, lyes the iest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, Ile goe with thee, prouide vs all things neceſſary, and meete me to morrow night in Eastcheape, there Ile ſup. Farewell. Poyn. Farewell, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: I know you all, and will a-while vphold
The vnyoak’d humor of your idleneſſe:
Yet heerein will I imitate the Sunne,
Who doth permit the base contagious cloudes
To ſmother vp his Beauty from the world,
That when he please againe to be himselfe,
Being wanted, he may be more wondred at,
By breaking through the foule and vgly mists
Of vapours, that did ſeeme to ſtrangle him.
If all the yeare were playing holidaies,
To ſport, would be as tedious as to worke;
But when they ſeldome come, they wisht-for come,
And nothing pleaseth but rare accidents.
So when this loose behauiour I throw off,
And pay the debt I neuer promised;
By how much better then my word I am,
By ſo much ſhall I falsifie mens hopes,
And like bright Mettall on a ſullen ground:
My reformation glittering o’re my fault,
Shall ſhew more goodly, and attract more eyes,
Then that which hath no foyle to ſet it off.
Ile ſo offend, to make offence a ſkill,
Redeeming time, when men thinke least I will.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the King, Northumberland, Worcester, Hotspurre, Sir Walter Blunt, and others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: My blood hath beene too cold and temperate,
Vnapt to ſtirre at these indignities,
And you haue found me; for accordingly,
You tread vpon my patience: But be ſure,
I will from henceforth rather be my Selfe,
Mighty, and to be fear’d, then my condition
Which hath beene ſmooth as Oyle, ſoft as yong Downe,
And therefore lost that Title of respect,
Which the proud ſoule ne're payes, but to the proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: Our house (my Soueraigne Liege) little deserues
The ſcourge of greatneſſe to be vsed on it,
And that ſame greatneſſe too, which our owne hands
Haue holpe to make ſo portly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nor.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Worcester get thee gone: for I do ſee
Danger and disobedience in thine eye.
O ſir, your presence is too bold and peremptory,
And Maiestie might neuer yet endure
The moody Frontier of a ſeruant brow,
You haue good leaue to leaue vs. When we need
Your vse and counsell, we ſhall ſend for you.
You were about to ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: North.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, my good Lord.
Those Prisoners in your Highneſſe demanded,
Which Harry Percy heere at Holmedon tooke,
Were (as he ſayes) not with ſuch ſtrength denied
As was deliuered to your Maiesty:
Who either through enuy, or misprision,
Was guilty of this fault; and not my Sonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: My Liege, I did deny no Prisoners.
But, I remember when the fight was done,
When I was dry with Rage, and extreame Toyle,
Breathleſſe, and Faint, leaning vpon my Sword,
Came there a certaine Lord, neat and trimly drest;
Fresh as a Bride-groome, and his Chin new reapt,
Shew’d like a ſtubble Land at Haruest home.
He was perfumed like a Milliner,
And 'twixt his Finger and his Thumbe, he held
A Pouncet-box: which euer and anon
He gaue his Nose, and took't away againe:
Who therewith angry, when it next came there,
Tooke it in Snuffe. And ſtill he ſmil’d and talk’d:
And as the Souldiers bare dead bodies by,
He call’d them vntaught Knaues, Vnmannerly,
To bring a ſlouenly vnhandsome Coarse
Betwixt the Winde, and his Nobility.
With many Holiday and Lady tearme
He question’d me: Among the rest, demanded
My Prisoners, in your Maiesties behalfe.
I then, all-smarting, with my wounds being cold,
(To be ſo pestered with a Popingay)
Out of my Greefe, and my Impatience,
Answer’d (neglectingly) I know not what,
He ſhould, or ſhould not: For he made me mad,
To ſee him ſhine ſo briske, and ſmell ſo ſweet,
And talke ſo like a Waiting-Gentlewoman,
Of Guns, & Drums, and Wounds: God ſaue the marke;
And telling me, the Soueraign'st thing on earth
Was Parmacity, for an inward bruise:
And that it was great pitty, ſo it was,
That villanous Salt-peter ſhould be digg’d
Out of the Bowels of the harmleſſe Earth,
Which many a good Tall Fellow had destroy’d
So Cowardly. And but for these vile Gunnes,
He would himselfe haue beene a Souldier.
This bald, vnioynted Chat of his (my Lord)
Made me to anſwer indirectly (as I ſaid.)
And I beseech you, let not this report
Come currant for an Accusation,
Betwixt my Loue, and your high Maiesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt.
SPEECH.LINE: The circumstance considered, good my Lord,
What euer Harry Percie then had ſaid,
To ſuch a person, and in ſuch a place,
At ſuch a time, with all the rest retold,
May reasonably dye, and neuer rise
To do him wrong, or any way impeach
What then he ſaid, ſo he vnsay it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Why yet doth deny his Prisoners,
But with Prouiso and Exception,
That we at our owne charge, ſhall ransome ſtraight
His Brother-in-Law, the foolish Mortimer,
Who (in my ſoule) hath wilfully betraid
The liues of those, that he did leade to Fight,
Against the great Magitian, damn’d Glendower:
Whose daughter (as we heare) the Earle of March
Hath lately married. Shall our Coffers then,
Be emptied, to redeeme a Traitor home?
Shall we buy Treason? and indent with Feares,
When they haue lost and forfeyted themselues.
No: on the barren Mountaine let him ſterue:
For I ſhall neuer hold that man my Friend,
Whose tongue ſhall aske me for one peny cost
To ransome home reuolted Mortimer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Reuolted Mortimer?
He neuer did fall off, my Soueraigne Liege,
But by the chance of Warre: to proue that true,
Needs no more but one tongue. For all those Wounds,
Those mouthed Wounds, which valiantly he tooke,
When on the gentle Seuernes ſiedgie banke,
In ſingle Opposition hand to hand,
He did confound the best part of an houre
In changing hardiment with great Glendower:
Three times they breath’d, and three times did they drink
Vpon agreement, of ſwift Seuernes flood;
Who then affrighted with their bloody lookes,
Ran fearefully among the trembling Reeds,
And hid his crispe-head in the hollow banke,
Blood-stained with these Valiant Combatants.
Neuer did base and rotten Policy
Colour her working with ſuch deadly wounds;
Nor neuer could the Noble Mortimer
Receiue ſo many, and all willingly:
Then let him not be ſland'red with Reuolt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou do'st bely him Percy, thou dost bely him;
He neuer did encounter with Glendower:
I tell thee, he durst as well haue met the diuell alone,
As Owen Glendower for an enemy.
Art thou not asham’d? But Sirrah, henceforth
Let me not heare you ſpeake of Mortimer.
Send me your Prisoners with the ſpeediest meanes,
Or you ſhall heare in ſuch a kinde from me
As will displease ye. My Lord Northumberland,
We License your departure with your ſonne,
Send vs your Prisoners, or you'l heare of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: And if the diuell come and roare for them
I will not ſend them. I will after ſtraight
And tell him ſo: for I will ease my heart,
Although it be with hazard of my head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nor.
SPEECH.LINE: What? drunke with choller? ſtay & pause awhile,
Heere comes your Vnckle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake of Mortimer?
Yes, I will ſpeake of him, and let my ſoule
Want mercy, if I do not ioyne with him.
In his behalfe, Ile empty all these Veines,
And ſhed my deere blood drop by drop i'th dust,
But I will lift the downfall Mortimer
As high i'th Ayre, as this Vnthankfull King,
As this Ingrate and Cankred Bullingbrooke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nor.
SPEECH.LINE: Brother, the King hath made your Nephew mad

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: Who ſtrooke this heate vp after I was gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: He will (forsooth) haue all my Prisoners:
And when I vrg’d the ransom once againe
Of my Wiues Brother, then his cheeke look’d pale,
And on my face he turn’d an eye of death,
Trembling euen at the name of Mortimer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot blame him: was he not proclaim’d
By Richard that dead is, the next of blood?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nor.
SPEECH.LINE: He was: I heard the Proclamation,
And then it was, when the vnhappy King
(Whose wrongs in vs God pardon) did ſet forth
Vpon his Irish Expedition:
From whence he intercepted, did returne
To be depos’d, and ſhortly murthered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: And for whose death, we in the worlds wide mouth
Liue ſcandaliz’d, and fouly ſpoken of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſoft I pray you; did King Richard then
Proclaime my brother Mortimer,
Heyre to the Crowne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nor.
SPEECH.LINE: He did, my ſelfe did heare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then I cannot blame his Cousin King,
That wish’d him on the barren Mountaines ſtaru’d.
But ſhall it be, that you that ſet the Crowne
Vpon the head of this forgetfull man,
And for his ſake, wore the detested blot
Of murtherous ſubornation? Shall it be,
That you a world of curses vndergœ,
Being the Agents, or base ſecond meanes,
The Cords, the Ladder, or the Hangman rather?
O pardon, if that I descend ſo low,
To ſhew the Line, and the Predicament
Wherein you range vnder this ſubtill King.
Shall it for ſhame, be ſpoken in these dayes,
Or fill vp Chronicles in time to come,
That men of your Nobility and Power,
Did gage them both in an vniust behalfe
(As Both of you, God pardon it, haue done)
To put downe Richard, that ſweet louely Rose,
And plant this Thorne, this Canker Bullingbrooke?
And ſhall it in more ſhame be further ſpoken,
That you are fool’d, discarded, and ſhooke off
By him, for whom these ſhames ye vnderwent?
No: yet time ſerues, wherein you may redeeme
Your banish’d Honors, and restore your ſelues
Into the good Thoughts of the world againe.
Reuenge the geering and disdain’d contempt
Of this proud King, who ſtudies day and night
To anſwer all the Debt he owes vnto you,
Euen with the bloody Payment of your deaths:
Therefore I ſay—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace Cousin, ſay no more.
And now I will vnclaspe a Secret booke,
And to your quicke conceyuing Discontents,
Ile reade you Matter, deepe and dangerous,
As full of perill and aduenturous Spirit,
As to o’re-walke a Current, roaring loud
On the vnstedfast footing of a Speare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: If he fall in, good night, or ſinke or ſwimme:
Send danger from the East vnto the West,
So Honor croſſe it from the North to South,
And let them grapple: The blood more ſtirres
To rowze a Lyon, then to ſtart a Hare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nor.
SPEECH.LINE: Imagination of ſome great exploit,
Driues him beyond the bounds of Patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: By heauen, me thinkes it were an easie leap,
To plucke bright Honor from the pale-fac’d Moone,
Or diue into the bottome of the deepe,
Where Fadome-line could neuer touch the ground,
And plucke vp drowned Honor by the Lockes:
So he that doth redeeme her thence, might weare
Without Co-riuall, all her Dignities:
But out vpon this halfe-fac’d Fellowship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: He apprehends a World of Figures here,
But not the forme of what he ſhould attend:
Good Cousin giue me audience for a-while,
And list to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: I cry you mercy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: Those ſame Noble Scottes
That are your Prisoners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile keepe them all.
By heauen, he ſhall not haue a Scot of them:
No, if a Scot would ſaue his Soule, he ſhall not.
Ile keepe them, by this Hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſtart away,
And lend no eare vnto my purposes.
Those Prisoners you ſhall keepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I will: that’s flat:
He ſaid, he would not ransome Mortimer:
Forbad my tongue to ſpeake of Mortimer.
But I will finde him when he lyes asleepe,
And in his eare, Ile holla Mortimer.
Nay, Ile haue a Starling ſhall be taught to ſpeake
Nothing but Mortimer, and giue it him,
To keepe his anger ſtill in motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare you Cousin: a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: All ſtudies heere I ſolemnly defie,
Saue how to gall and pinch this Bullingbrooke,
And that ſame Sword and Buckler Prince of Wales.
But that I thinke his Father loues him not,
And would be glad he met with ſome mischance,
I would haue poyson’d him with a pot of Ale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell Kinsman: Ile talke to you
When you are better temper’d to attend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nor.
SPEECH.LINE: Why what a Waspe-tongu’d & impatient foole
Art thou, to breake into this Womans mood,
Tying thine eare to no tongue but thine owne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Why look you, I am whipt & ſcourg’d with rods,
Netled, and ſtung with Pismires, when I heare
Of this vile Politician Bullingbrooke.
In Richards time: What de'ye call the place?
A plague vpon't, it is in Gloustershire:
'Twas, where the madcap Duke his Vncle kept,
His Vncle Yorke, where I first bow’d my knee
Vnto this King of Smiles, this Bullingbrooke:
When you and he came backe from Rauenspurgh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nor.
SPEECH.LINE: At Barkley Castle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſay true:
Why what a caudie deale of curtesie,
This fawning Grey-hound then did proffer me,
Looke when his infant Fortune came to age,
And gentle Harry Percy, and kinde Cousin:
O, the Diuell take ſuch Couzeners, God forgiue me,
Good Vncle tell your tale, for I haue done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, if you haue not, too't againe,
Wee'l ſtay your leysure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue done insooth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: Then once more to your Scottish Prisoners.
Deliuer them vp without their ransome ſtraight,
And make the Dowglas ſonne your onely meane
For powres in Scotland: which for diuers reasons
Which I ſhall ſend you written, be aſſur’d
Will easily be granted you, my Lord.
Your Sonne in Scotland being thus imploy’d,
Shall ſecretly into the bosome creepe
Of that ſame noble Prelate, well belou’d,
The Archbishop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Of Yorke, is't not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: True, who beares hard
His Brothers death at Bristow, the Lord Scroope.
I ſpeake not this in estimation,
As what I thinke might be, but what I know
Is ruminated, plotted, and ſet downe,
And onely ſtayes but to behold the face
Of that occasion that ſhall bring it on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſmell it:
Vpon my life, it will do wond'rous well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nor.
SPEECH.LINE: Before the game's a-foot, thou ſtill let'st ſlip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, it cannot choose but be a Noble plot,
And then the power of Scotland, and of Yorke
To ioyne with Mortimer, Ha.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo they ſhall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Infaith it is exceedingly well aym’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: And ‘tis no little reason bids vs ſpeed,
To ſaue our heads, by raising of a Head:
For, beare our ſelues as euen as we can,
The King will alwayes thinke him in our debt,
And thinke, we thinke our ſelues vnsatisfied,
Till he hath found a time to pay vs home.
And ſee already, how he doth beginne
To make vs ſtrangers to his lookes of loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: He does, he does; wee'l be reueng’d on him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wor.
SPEECH.LINE: Cousin, farewell. No further go in this,
Then I by Letters ſhall direct your course
When time is ripe, which will be ſodainly:
Ile ſteale to Glendower, and lœ, Mortimer,
Where you, and Dowglas, and our powres at once,
As I will fashion it, ſhall happily meete,
To beare our fortunes in our owne ſtrong armes,
Which now we hold at much vncertainty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nor.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell good Brother, we ſhall thriue, I trust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Vncle, adieu: O let the houres be ſhort,
Till fields, and blowes, and grones, applaud our ſport.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a Carrier with a Lanterne in his hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: Heigh-ho, an't be not foure by the day, Ile be hang’d. Charles waine is ouer the new Chimney, and yet our horse not packt. What Ostler?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ost.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon, anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: I prethee Tom, beate Cuts Saddle, put a few Flockes in the point: the poore Iade is wrung in the wi-thers, out of all ceſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: Pease and Beanes are as danke here as a Dog, and this is the next way to giue poore Iades the Bottes: This house is turned vpside downe ſince Robin the Ostler dyed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: Poore fellow neuer ioy’d ſince the price of oats rose, it was the death of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke this is the mo’t villanous house in al
London rode for Fleas: I am ſtung like a Tench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: Like a Tench? There is ne're a King in Chri-stendome, could be better bit, then I haue beene ſince the first Cocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, you will allow vs ne're a Iourden, and then we leake in your Chimney: and your Chamber-lye breeds Fleas like a Loach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: What Ostler, come away, and be hangd: come away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue a Gammon of Bacon, and two razes of
Ginger, to be deliuered as farre as Charing-croſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: The Turkies in my Pannier are quite ſtarued. What Ostler? A plague on thee, hast thou neuer an eye in thy head? Can'st not heare? And t'were not as good a deed as drinke, to break the pate of thee, I am a very Vil-laine. Come and be hang’d, hast no faith in thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: Good-morrow Carriers. What's a clocke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Car.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke it be two a clocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: I prethee lend me thy Lanthorne to ſee my Gel-ding in the ſtable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay ſoft I pray ye, I know a trick worth two of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: I prethee lend me thine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: I, when, canst tell? Lend mee thy Lanthorne
(quoth-a) marry Ile ſee thee hang’d first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra Carrier: What time do you mean to come to London?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Car.
SPEECH.LINE: Time enough to goe to bed with a Candle, I warrant thee. Come neighbour Mugges, wee'll call vp the Gentlemen, they will along with company, for they haue great charge. Exeunt

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: What ho, Chamberlaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cham.
SPEECH.LINE: At hand quoth Pick-purse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: That's euen as faire, as at hand quoth the Cham-berlaine: For thou variest no more from picking of Pur-ses, then giuing direction, doth from labouring. Thou lay'st the plot, how.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cham.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow Master Gads-Hill, it holds cur-rant that I told you yesternight. There's a Franklin in the wilde of Kent, hath brought three hundred Markes with him in Gold: I heard him tell it to one of his company last night at Supper; a kinde of Auditor, one that hath abun-dance of charge too (God knowes what) they are vp al-ready, and call for Egges and Butter. They will away presently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra, if they meete not with S[aint]. Nicholas Clarks,
Ile giue thee this necke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cham.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Ile none of it: I prythee keep that for the Hangman, for I know thou worshipst S[aint]. Nicholas as tru-ly as a man of falshood may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: What talkest thou to me of the Hangman? If I hang, Ile make a fat payre of Gallowes. For, if I hang, old Sir Iohn hangs with mee, and thou know'st hee's no Starueling. Tut, there are other Troians that y dream'st not of, the which (for ſport ſake) are content to doe the Profeſſion ſome grace; that would (if matters ſhould bee look’d into) for their owne Credit ſake, make all Whole. I am ioyned with no Foot-land-Rakers, No Long-staffe ſix-penny ſtrikers, none of these mad Mustachio-purple-hu’d-Maltwormes, but with Nobility, and Tranquilitie; Bourgomasters, and great Oneyers, ſuch as can holde in, ſuch as will ſtrike ſooner then ſpeake; and ſpeake ſooner then drinke, and drinke ſooner then pray: and yet I lye, for they pray continually vnto their Saint the Common-wealth; or rather, not to pray to her, but prey on her: for they ride vp & downe on her, and make hir their Boots.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cham.
SPEECH.LINE: What, the Commonwealth their Bootes? Will ſhe hold out water in foule way?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: She will, ſhe will; Iustice hath liquor’d her. We ſteale as in a Castle, cocksure: we haue the receit of Fern-seede, we walke inuisible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I thinke rather, you are more beholding to the Night, then to the Fernseed, for your walking in-uisible. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me thy hand.
Thou ſhalt haue a ſhare in our purpose,
As I am a true man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, rather let mee haue it, as you are a false
Theefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe too: Homo is a common name to all men. Bid the Ostler bring the Gelding out of the ſtable. Fare-well, ye muddy Knaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poines.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſhelter, ſhelter, I haue remoued Falstafs
Horse, and he frets like a gum’d Veluet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand close.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Poines, Poines, and be hang’d Poines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace ye fat-kidney’d Rascall, what a brawling dost thou keepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What Poines. Hal?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: He is walk’d vp to the top of the hill, Ile go ſeek him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I am accurst to rob in that Theefe company: that Rascall hath remoued my Horse, and tied him I know not where. If I trauell but foure foot by the ſquire further a foote, I ſhall breake my winde. Well, I doubt not but to dye a faire death for all this, if I ſcape hanging for kil-ling that Rogue, I haue forsworne his company hourely any time this two and twenty yeare, & yet I am bewitcht with the Rogues company. If the Rascall haue not giuen me medicines to make me loue him, Ile be hang’d; it could not be else: I haue drunke Medicines. Poines, Hal, a Plague vpon you both. Bardolph, Peto: Ile ſtarue ere I rob a foote further. And 'twere not as good a deede as to drinke, to turne True-man, and to leaue these Rogues, I am the veriest Varlet that euer chewed with a Tooth. Eight yards of vneuen ground, is threescore & ten miles afoot with me: and the ſtony-hearted Villaines knowe it well enough. A plague vpon't, when Theeues cannot be true one to another. They Whistle. Whew: a plague light vpon you all. Giue my Horse you Rogues: giue me my Horse, and be hang’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace ye fat guttes, lye downe, lay thine eare close to the ground, and list if thou can heare the tread of Trauellers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you any Leauers to lift me vp again being downe? Ile not beare mine owne flesh ſo far afoot again, for all the coine in thy Fathers Exchequer. What a plague meane ye to colt me thus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ly'st, thou art not colted, thou art vncolted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I prethee good Prince Hal, help me to my horse, good Kings ſonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Out you Rogue, ſhall I be your Ostler?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Go hang thy ſelfe in thine owne heire-apparant-Garters: If I be tane, Ile peach for this: and I haue not Ballads made on all, and ſung to filthy tunes, let a Cup of Sacke be my poyson: when a iest is ſo forward, & a foote too, I hate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: So I do against my will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: O ‘tis our Setter, I know his voyce:
Bardolfe, what newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Case ye, case ye; on with your Vizards, there's mony of the Kings comming downe the hill, ‘tis going to the Kings Exchequer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: You lie you rogue, ‘tis going to the Kings Tauern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: There's enough to make vs all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: To be hang’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: You foure ſhall front them in the narrow Lane: Ned and I, will walke lower; if they ſcape from your en-counter, then they light on vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peto.
SPEECH.LINE: But how many be of them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: Some eight or ten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Will they not rob vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: What, a Coward Sir Iohn Paunch?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed I am not Iohn of Gaunt your Grandfather; but yet no Coward, Hal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'l leaue that to the proofe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra Iacke, thy horse ſtands behinde the hedg, when thou need'st him, there thou ſhalt finde him. Fare-well, and ſtand fast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Now cannot I ſtrike him, if I ſhould be hang’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Ned, where are our disguises?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere hard by: Stand close.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Now my Masters, happy man be his dole, ſay I: euery man to his busineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Neighbor: the boy ſhall leade our Horses downe the hill: Wee'l walke a-foot a while, and ease our Legges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theeues.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: Iesu bleſſe vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Strike down with them, cut the villains throats; a whorson Caterpillars: Bacon-fed Knaues, they hate vs youth; downe with them, fleece them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tra.
SPEECH.LINE: O, we are vndone, both we and ours for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang ye gorbellied knaues, are you vndone? No ye Fat Chuffes, I would your ſtore were heere. On Ba-cons, on, what ye knaues? Yong men must liue, you are Grand Iurers, are ye? Wee'l iure ye ifaith. Heere they rob them, and binde them. Enter the Prince and Poines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: The Theeues haue bound the True-men: Now could thou and I rob the Theeues, and go merily to Lon-don, it would be argument for a Weeke, Laughter for a Moneth, and a good iest for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poynes.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand close, I heare them comming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Come my Masters, let vs ſhare, and then to horſſe before day: and the Prince and Poynes bee not two ar-rand Cowards, there's no equity ſtirring. There's no moe valour in that Poynes, than in a wilde Ducke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Your money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Villaines.
As they are ſharing, the Prince and Poynes ſet vpon them.
They all run away, leauing the booty behind them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Got with much ease. Now merrily to Horse: The Theeues are ſcattred, and poſſest with fear ſo ſtrong-ly, that they dare not meet each other: each takes his fel-low for an Officer. Away good Ned, Falstaffe ſweates to death, and Lards the leane earth as he walkes along: wer't not for laughing, I ſhould pitty him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: How the Rogue roar’d.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Hotspurre ſolus, reading a Letter.

SPEECH.LINE: But for mine owne part, my Lord. I could bee well contented to be there, in respect of the loue I beare your house. He could be contented: Why is he not then? in respect of the loue he beares our house. He ſhewes in this, he loues his owne Barne better then he loues our house. Let me ſee ſome more. The purpose you vndertake is dangerous. Why that’s certaine: ‘Tis dangerous to take a Colde, to ſleepe, to drinke: but I tell you (my Lord foole) out of this Nettle, Danger; we plucke this Flower, Safety. The purpose you vndertake is dangerous, the Friends you haue na-med vncertaine, the Time it ſelfe vnsorted, and your whole Plot too light, for the counterpoize of ſo great an Opposition. Say you ſo, ſay you ſo: I ſay vnto you againe, you are a ſhallow cowardly Hinde, and you Lye. What a lacke-braine is this? I protest, our plot is as good a plot as euer was laid; our Friend true and constant: A good Plotte, good Friends, and full of expectation: An excellent plot, very good Friends. What a Frosty-spirited rogue is this? Why, my Lord of Yorke commends the plot, and the generall course of the action. By this hand, if I were now by this Rascall, I could braine him with his Ladies Fan. Is there not my Father, my Vncle, and my Selfe, Lord Edmund Mortimer, my Lord of Yorke, and Owen Glendour? Is there not besides, the Dowglas? Haue I not all their let-ters, to meete me in Armes by the ninth of the next Mo-neth? and are they not ſome of them ſet forward already? What a Pagan Rascall is this? An Infidell. Ha, you ſhall ſee now in very ſincerity of Feare and Cold heart, will he to the King, and lay open all our proceedings. O, I could diuide my ſelfe, and go to buffets, for mouing ſuch a dish of ſkim’d Milk with ſo honourable an Action. Hang him, let him tell the King we are prepared. I will ſet forwards to night.
How now Kate, I must leaue you within these two hours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: O my good Lord, why are you thus alone?
For what offence haue I this fortnight bin
A banish’d woman from my Harries bed?
Tell me (sweet Lord) what is't that takes from thee
Thy ſtomacke, pleasure, and thy golden ſleepe?
Why dost thou bend thine eyes vpon the earth?
And ſtart ſo often when thou ſitt'st alone?
Why hast thou lost the fresh blood in thy cheekes?
And giuen my Treasures and my rights of thee,
To thicke-ey’d musing, and curst melancholly?
In my faint-slumbers, I by thee haue watcht,
And heard thee murmore tales of Iron Warres:
Speake tearmes of manage to thy bounding Steed,
Cry courage to the field. And thou hast talk’d
Of Sallies, and Retires; Trenches, Tents,
Of Palizadœs, Frontiers, Parapets,
Of Basiliskes, of Canon, Culuerin,
Of Prisoners ransome, and of Souldiers ſlaine,
And all the current of a headdy fight.
Thy ſpirit within thee hath beene ſo at Warre,
And thus hath ſo bestirr’d thee in thy ſleepe,
That beds of ſweate hath ſtood vpon thy Brow,
Like bubbles in a late-disturbed Streame;
And in thy face ſtrange motions haue appear’d,
Such as we ſee when men restraine their breath
On ſome great ſodaine hast. O what portents are these?
Some heauie busineſſe hath my Lord in hand,
And I must know it: else he loues me not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: What ho; Is Gilliams with the Packet gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: He is my Lord, an houre agone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath Butler brought those horses fro[m] the Sheriffe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: One horse, my Lord, he brought euen now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: What Horse? A Roane, a crop eare, is it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: It is my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: That Roane ſhall be my Throne. Well, I will backe him ſtraight. Esperance, bid Butler lead him forth into the Parke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: But heare you, my lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay'st thou my Lady?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: What is it carries you away?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, my horse (my Loue) my horse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Out you mad-headed Ape, a Weazell hath not ſuch a deale of Spleene, as you are tost with. In ſooth Ile know your busineſſe Harry, that I will. I feare my Bro-ther Mortimer doth ſtirre about his Title, and hath ſent for you to line his enterprize. But if you go—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: So farre a foot, I ſhall be weary, Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, you Paraquito, anſwer me directly vnto this question, that I ſhall aske. Indeede Ile breake thy little finger Harry, if thou wilt not tel me true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, away you trifler: Loue, I loue thee not,
I care not for thee Kate: this is no world
To play with Mammets, and to tilt with lips.
We must haue bloodie Noses, and crack’d Crownes,
And paſſe them currant too. Gods me, my horse.
What ſay'st thou Kate? what wold'st thou haue with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Do ye not loue me? Do ye not indeed?
Well, do not then. For ſince you loue me not,
I will not loue my ſelfe. Do you not loue me?
Nay, tell me if thou ſpeak'st in iest, or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, wilt thou ſee me ride?
And when I am a horsebacke, I will ſweare
I loue thee infinitely. But hearke you Kate,
I must not haue you henceforth, question me,
Whether I go: nor reason whereabout.
Whether I must, I must: and to conclude,
This Euening must I leaue thee, gentle Kate.
I know you wise, but yet no further wise
Then Harry Percies wife. Constant you are,
But yet a woman: and for ſecrecie,
No Lady closer. For I will beleeue
Thou wilt not vtter what thou do'st not know,
And ſo farre wilt I trust thee, gentle Kate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſo farre?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hot.
SPEECH.LINE: Not an inch further. But harke you Kate,
Whither I go, thither ſhall you go too:
To day will I ſet forth, to morrow you.
Will this content you Kate?
La. It must of force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Ned, prethee come out of that fat roome, & lend me thy hand to laugh a little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poines.
SPEECH.LINE: Where hast bene Hall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: With three or foure Logger-heads, amongst 3. or fourescore Hogsheads. I haue ſounded the verie base ſtring of humility. Sirra, I am ſworn brother to a leash of Drawers, and can call them by their names, as Tom, Dicke, and Francis. They take it already vpon their confidence, that though I be but Prince of Wales, yet I am the King of Curtesie: telling me flatly I am no proud Iack like Fal-staffe, but a Corinthian, a lad of mettle, a good boy, and when I am King of England, I ſhall command al the good Laddes in East-cheape. They call drinking deepe, dy-ing Scarlet; and when you breath in your watering, then they cry hem, and bid you play it off. To conclude, I am ſo good a proficient in one quarter of an houre, that I can drinke with any Tinker in his owne Language during my life. I tell thee Ned, thou hast lost much honor, that thou wer't not with me in this action: but ſweet Ned, to ſwee-ten which name of Ned, I giue thee this peniworth of Su-gar, clapt euen now into my hand by an vnder Skinker, one that neuer ſpake other English in his life, then Eight ſhillings and ſix pence, and, You are welcome: with this ſhril addition, Anon, Anon ſir, Score a Pint of Bastard in the Halfe Moone, or ſo. But Ned, to driue away time till Fal-staffe come, I prythee doe thou ſtand in ſome by-roome, while I question my puny Drawer, to what end hee gaue me the Sugar, and do neuer leaue calling Francis, that his Tale to me may be nothing but, Anon: ſtep aside, and Ile ſhew thee a President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poines.
SPEECH.LINE: Francis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art perfect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Francis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon, anon ſir; looke downe into the Pomgar-net,
Ralfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither Francis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: How long hast thou to ſerue, Francis?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Forsooth fiue yeares, and as much as to—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Francis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon, anon ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Fiue yeares: Berlady a long Lease for the clin-king of Pewter. But Francis, darest thou be ſo valiant, as to play the coward with thy Indenture, & ſhow it a faire paire of heeles, and run from it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir, Ile be ſworne vpon all the Books in
England, I could finde in my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Francis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon, anon ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: How old art thou, Francis?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me ſee, about Michaelmas next I ſhalbe—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Francis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon ſir, pray you ſtay a little, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay but harke you Francis, for the Sugar thou gauest me, 'twas a penyworth, was't not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir, I would it had bene two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: I will giue thee for it a thousand pound: Aske me when thou wilt, and thou ſhalt haue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Francis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon, anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon Francis? No Francis, but to morrow Fran-cis: or Francis, on thursday: or indeed Francis when thou wilt. But Francis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou rob this Leatherne Ierkin, Christall button, Not-pated, Agat ring, Puke ſtocking, Caddice garter, Smooth tongue, Spanish pouch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir, who do you meane?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then your browne Bastard is your onely drinke: for looke you Francis, your white Canuas doub-let will ſulley. In Barbary ſir, it cannot come to ſo much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Francis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Away you Rogue, dost thou heare them call? Heere they both call him, the Drawer ſtands amazed, not knowing which way to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vint.
SPEECH.LINE: What, ſtand'st thou ſtill, and hear'st ſuch a cal-ling? Looke to the Guests within: My Lord, olde Sir Iohn with halfe a dozen more, are at the doore: ſhall I let them in?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Let them alone awhile, and then open the doore.
Poines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon, anon ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra, Falstaffe and the rest of the Theeues, are at the doore, ſhall we be merry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: As merrie as Crickets my Lad. But harke yee,
What cunning match haue you made this iest of the
Drawer? Come, what’s the iſſue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: I am now of all humors, that haue ſhewed them-selues humors, ſince the old dayes of goodman Adam, to the pupill age of this present twelue a clock at midnight. What's a clocke Francis?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon, anon ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: That euer this Fellow ſhould haue fewer words then a Parret, and yet the ſonne of a Woman. His indu-stry is vp-staires and down-staires, his eloquence the par-cell of a reckoning. I am not yet of Percies mind, the Hot-spurre of the North, he that killes me ſome ſixe or ſeauen dozen of Scots at a Breakfast, washes his hands, and ſaies to his wife; Fie vpon this quiet life, I want worke. O my ſweet Harry ſayes ſhe, how many hast thou kill’d to day? Giue my Roane horse a drench (sayes hee) and answeres, ſome fourteene, an houre after: a trifle, a trifle. I prethee call in Falstaffe, Ile play Percy, and that damn’d Brawne ſhall play Dame Mortimer his wife. Riuo, ſayes the drun-kard. Call in Ribs, call in Tallow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome Iacke, where hast thou beene?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: A plague of all Cowards I ſay, and a Vengeance too, marry and Amen. Giue me a cup of Sacke Boy. Ere I leade this life long, Ile ſowe nether ſtockes, and mend them too. A plague of all cowards. Giue me a Cup of Sacke, Rogue. Is there no Vertue extant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Didst thou neuer ſee Titan kiſſe a dish of Butter, pittifull hearted Titan that melted at the ſweete Tale of the Sunne? If thou didst, then behold that compound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: You Rogue, heere's Lime in this Sacke too: there is nothing but Roguery to be found in Villanous man; yet a Coward is worse then a Cup of Sack with lime. A vil-lanous Coward, go thy wayes old Iacke, die when thou wilt, if manhood, good manhood be not forgot vpon the face of the earth, then am I a ſhotten Herring: there liues not three good men vnhang’d in England, & one of them is fat, and growes old, God helpe the while, a bad world I ſay. I would I were a Weauer, I could ſing all manner of ſongs. A plague of all Cowards, I ſay ſtill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Woolsacke, what mutter you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: A Kings Sonne? If I do not beate thee out of thy Kingdome with a dagger of Lath, and driue all thy Sub-iects afore thee like a flocke of Wilde-geese, Ile neuer weare haire on my face more. You Prince of Wales?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why you horson round man? what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you not a Coward? Answer me to that, and
Poines there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Ye fat paunch, and yee call mee Coward, Ile ſtab thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I call thee Coward? Ile ſee thee damn’d ere I call the Coward: but I would giue a thousand pound I could run as fast as thou canst. You are ſtraight enough in the ſhoulders, you care not who ſees your backe: Call you that backing of your friends? a plague vpon ſuch bac-king: giue me them that will face me. Giue me a Cup of Sack, I am a Rogue if I drunke to day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: O Villaine, thy Lippes are ſcarce wip’d, ſince thou drunk'st last. Falst. All's one for that. He drinkes. A plague of all Cowards ſtill, ſay I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter? here be foure of vs, haue ta'ne a thousand pound this Morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is it, Iack? where is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is it? taken from vs, it is: a hundred vpon poore foure of vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: What, a hundred, man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a Rogue, if I were not at halfe Sword with a dozen of them two houres together. I haue ſcaped by miracle. I am eight times thrust through the Doublet, foure through the Hose, my Buckler cut through and through, my Sword hackt like a Hand-saw, ecce ſignum. I neuer dealt better ſince I was a man: all would not doe. A plague of all Cowards: let them ſpeake; if they ſpeake more or leſſe then truth, they are villaines, and the ſonnes of darkneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake ſirs, how was it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: We foure ſet vpon ſome dozen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Sixteene, at least, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: And bound them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peto.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, they were not bound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: You Rogue, they were bound, euery man of them, or I am a Iew else, an Ebrew Iew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gad.
SPEECH.LINE: As we were ſharing, ſome ſixe or ſeuen fresh men ſet vpon vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: And vnbound the rest, and then come in the other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: What, fought yee with them all?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: All? I know not what yee call all: but if I fought not with fiftie of them, I am a bunch of Radish: if there were not two or three and fiftie vpon poore olde Iack, then am I no two-legg’d Creature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray Heauen, you haue not murthered ſome of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, that’s past praying for, I haue pepper’d two of them: Two I am ſure I haue payed, two Rogues in Buckrom Sutes. I tell thee what, Hal, if I tell thee a Lye, ſpit in my face, call me Horse: thou knowest my olde word: here I lay, and thus I bore my point; foure Rogues in Buckrom let driue at me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: What, foure? thou ſayd'st but two, euen now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Foure Hal, I told thee foure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I, he ſaid foure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: These foure came all a-front, and mainely thrust at me; I made no more adœ, but tooke all their ſeuen points in my Targuet, thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Seuen? why there were but foure, euen now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: In buckrom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: I, foure, in Buckrom Sutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Seuen, by these Hilts, or I am a Villaine else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Prethee let him alone, we ſhall haue more anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Doest thou heare me, Hal?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and marke thee too, Iack.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe ſo, for it is worth the listning too: these nine in Buckrom, that I told thee of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: So, two more alreadie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Their Points being broken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Downe fell his Hose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Began to giue me ground: but I followed me close, came in foot and hand; and with a thought, ſeuen of the eleuen I pay’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: O monstrous! eleuen Buckrom men growne out of two?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: But as the Deuill would haue it, three mis-be-gotten Knaues, in Kendall Greene, came at my Back, and let driue at me; for it was ſo darke, Hal, that thou could'st not ſee thy Hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: These Lyes are like the Father that begets them, groſſe as a Mountaine, open, palpable. Why thou Clay-brayn’d Guts, thou Knotty-pated Foole, thou Horson ob-scene greasie Tallow Catch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: What, art thou mad? art thou mad? is not the truth, the truth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, how could'st thou know these men in Kendall Greene, when it was ſo darke, thou could'st not ſee thy Hand? Come, tell vs your reason: what ſay'st thou to this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, your reason Iack, your reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: What, vpon compulsion? No: were I at the Strappado, or all the Racks in the World, I would not tell you on compulsion. Giue you a reason on compulsi-on? If Reasons were as plentie as Black-berries, I would giue no man a Reason vpon compulsion, I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile be no longer guiltie of this ſinne. This ſan-guine Coward, this Bed-preſſer, this Hors-back-breaker, this huge Hill of Flesh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Away you Starueling, you Elfe-skin, you dried Neats tongue, Bulles-piſſell, you ſtocke-fish: O for breth to vtter. What is like thee? You Tailors yard, you ſheath you Bow-case, you vile ſtanding tucke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, breath a-while, and then to't againe: and when thou hast tyr’d thy ſelfe in base comparisons, heare me ſpeake but thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: Marke Iacke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: We two, ſaw you foure ſet on foure and bound them, and were Masters of their Wealth: mark now how a plaine Tale ſhall put you downe. Then did we two, ſet on you foure, and with a word, outfac’d you from your prize, and haue it: yea, and can ſhew it you in the House. And Falstaffe, you caried your Guts away as nimbly, with as quicke dexteritie, and roared for mercy, and ſtill ranne and roar’d, as euer I heard Bull-Calfe. What a Slaue art thou, to hacke thy ſword as thou hast done, and then ſay it was in fight. What trick? what deuice? what ſtarting hole canst thou now find out, to hide thee from this open and apparant ſhame?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poines.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, let's heare Iacke: What tricke hast thou now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I knew ye as well as he that made ye. Why heare ye my Masters, was it for me to kill the Heire apparant? Should I turne vpon the true Prince? Why, thou knowest I am as valiant as Hercules: but beware Instinct, the Lion will not touch the true Prince: Instinct is a great matter. I was a Coward on Instinct: I ſhall thinke the better of my ſelfe, and thee, during my life: I, for a valiant Lion, and thou for a true Prince. But Lads, I am glad you haue the Mony. Hosteſſe, clap to the doores: watch to night, pray to morrow. Gallants, Lads, Boyes, Harts of Gold, all the good Titles of Fellowship come to you. What, ſhall we be merry? ſhall we haue a Play extempory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Content, and the argument ſhall be, thy runing away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: A, no more of that Hall, and thou louest me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Host.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, the Prince?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: How now my Lady the Hosteſſe, what ſay'st thou to me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hosteſſe.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, my Lord, there is a Noble man of the Court at doore would ſpeake with you: hee ſayes, hee comes from your Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue him as much as will make him a Royall man, and ſend him backe againe to my Mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: What manner of man is hee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hosteſſe.
SPEECH.LINE: An old man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: What doth Grauitie out of his Bed at Midnight?
Shall I giue him his answere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Prethee doe Iacke.
Falst. 'Faith, and Ile ſend him packing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Sirs: you fought faire; ſo did you Peto, ſo did you Bardol: you are Lyons too, you ranne away vpon instinct: you will not touch the true Prince; no, fie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bard.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Faith, I ranne when I ſaw others runne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell mee now in earnest, how came Falstaffes
Sword ſo hackt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peto.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, he hackt it with his Dagger, and ſaid, hee would ſweare truth out of England, but hee would make you beleeue it was done in fight, and perswaded vs to doe the like.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bard.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, and to tickle our Noses with Spear-graſſe, to make them bleed, and then to beslubber our garments with it, and ſweare it was the blood of true men. I did that I did not this ſeuen yeeres before, I blusht to heare his monstrous deuices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: O Villaine, thou ſtolest a Cup of Sacke eigh-teene yeeres agœ, and wert taken with the manner, and euer ſince thou hast blusht extempore: thou hadst fire and ſword on thy ſide, and yet thou ranst away; what instinct hadst thou for it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bard.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, doe you ſee these Meteors? doe you behold these Exhalations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bard.
SPEECH.LINE: What thinke you they portend?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Hot Liuers, and cold Purses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bard.
SPEECH.LINE: Choler, my Lord, if rightly taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: No, if rightly taken, Halter. Enter Falstaffe. Heere comes leane Iacke, heere comes bare-bone. How now my ſweet Creature of Bombast, how long is't agœ, Iacke, ſince thou ſaw'st thine owne Knee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: My owne Knee? When I was about thy yeeres (Hal) I was not an Eagles Talent in the Waste, I could haue crept into any Aldermans Thumbe-Ring: a plague of ſighing and griefe, it blowes a man vp like a Bladder. There's villanous Newes abroad; heere was Sir Iohn Braby from your Father; you must goe to the Court in the Morning. The ſame mad fellow of the North, Percy; and hee of Wales, that gaue Amamon the Bastinado, and made Lucifer Cuckold, and ſwore the Deuill his true Liege-man vpon the Croſſe of a Welch-hooke; what a plague call you him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Poin.
SPEECH.LINE: O, Glendower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Owen, Owen; the ſame, and his Sonne in Law
Mortimer, and old Northumberland, and the ſprightly
Scot of Scots, Dowglas, that runnes a Horse-backe vp a
Hill perpendicular.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee that rides at high ſpeede, and with a Pistoll kills a Sparrow flying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue hit it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: So did he neuer the Sparrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, that Rascall hath good mettall in him, hee will not runne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what a Rascall art thou then, to prayse him ſo for running?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: A Horse-backe (ye Cuckœ) but a foot hee will not budge a foot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes Iacke, vpon instinct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: I grant ye, vpon instinct: Well, hee is there too, and one Mordake, and a thousand blew-Cappes more. Worcester is ſtolne away by Night: thy Fathers Beard is turn’d white with the Newes; you may buy Land now as cheape as ſtinking Mackrell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ‘tis like, if there come a hot Sunne, and this ciuill buffetting hold, wee ſhall buy Maiden-heads as they buy Hob-nayles, by the Hundreds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: By the Maſſe Lad, thou ſay'st true, it is like wee ſhall haue good trading that way. But tell me Hal, art not thou horrible afear’d? thou being Heire apparant, could the World picke thee out three ſuch Enemyes a-gaine, as that Fiend Dowglas, that Spirit Percy, and that Deuill Glendower? Art not thou horrible afraid? Doth not thy blood thrill at it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a whit: I lacke ſome of thy instinct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, thou wilt be horrible chidde to morrow, when thou commest to thy Father: if thou doe loue me, practise an answere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe thou ſtand for my Father, and examine mee vpon the particulars of my Life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I? content: This Chayre ſhall bee my
State, this Dagger my Scepter, and this Cushion my
Crowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy State is taken for a Ioyn’d-Stoole, thy Gol-den
Scepter for a Leaden Dagger, and thy precious rich
Crowne, for a pittifull bald Crowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, and the fire of Grace be not quite out of thee now ſhalt thou be moued. Giue me a Cup of Sacke to make mine eyes looke redde, that it may be thought I haue wept, for I must ſpeake in paſſion, and I will doe it in King Cambyses vaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, heere is my Legge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: And heere is my ſpeech: ſtand aside Nobilitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hosteſſe.
SPEECH.LINE: This is excellent ſport, yfaith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Weepe not, ſweet Queene, for trickling teares are vaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hosteſſe.
SPEECH.LINE: O the Father, how hee holdes his counte-nance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: For Gods ſake Lords, conuey my trustfull Queen,
For teares doe ſtop the floud-gates of her eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hosteſſe.
SPEECH.LINE: O rare, he doth it as like one of these harlotry
Players, as euer I ſee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace good Pint-pot, peace good Tickle-braine. Harry, I doe not onely maruell where thou ſpendest thy time; but also, how thou art accompanied: For though the Camomile, the more it is troden, the faster it growes; yet Youth, the more it is wasted, the ſooner it weares. Thou art my Sonne: I haue partly thy Mothers Word, partly my Opinion; but chiefely, a villanous tricke of thine Eye, and a foolish hanging of thy nether Lippe, that doth warrant me. If then thou be Sonne to mee, heere lyeth the point: why, being Sonne to me, art thou ſo poynted at? Shall the bleſſed Sonne of Heauen proue a Micher, and eate Black-berryes? a question not to bee askt. Shall the Sonne of England proue a Theefe, and take Purses? a question to be askt. There is a thing, Harry, which thou hast often heard of, and it is knowne to many in our Land, by the Name of Pitch: this Pitch (as ancient Writers doe report) doth defile; ſo doth the com-panie thou keepest: for Harry, now I doe not ſpeake to thee in Drinke, but in Teares; not in Pleasure, but in Pas-sion; not in Words onely, but in Wœs also: and yet there is a vertuous man, whom I haue often noted in thy companie, but I know not his Name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: What manner of man, and it like your Ma-iestie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: A goodly portly man yfaith, and a corpulent, of a chearefull Looke, a pleasing Eye, and a mo’t noble Carriage, and as I thinke, his age ſome fiftie, or (byrlady) inclining to threescore; and now I remember mee, his Name is Falstaffe: if that man ſhould be lewdly giuen, hee deceiues mee; for Harry, I ſee Vertue in his Lookes. If then the Tree may be knowne by the Fruit, as the Fruit by the Tree, then peremptorily I ſpeake it, there is Vertue in that Falstaffe: him keepe with, the rest banish. And tell mee now, thou naughtie Varlet, tell mee, where hast thou beene this moneth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Do'st thou ſpeake like a King? doe thou ſtand for mee, and Ile play my Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Depose me: if thou do'st it halfe ſo grauely, ſo maiestically, both in word and matter, hang me vp by the heeles for a Rabbet-sucker, or a Poulters Hare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, heere I am ſet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: And heere I ſtand: iudge my Masters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Harry, whence come you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: My Noble Lord, from East-cheape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: The complaints I heare of thee, are grieuous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Yfaith, my Lord, they are false: Nay, Ile tickle ye for a young Prince.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Swearest thou, vngracious Boy? henceforth ne're looke on me: thou art violently carryed away from Grace: there is a Deuill haunts thee, in the likeneſſe of a fat old Man; a Tunne of Man is thy Companion: Why do'st thou conuerse with that Trunke of Humors, that Boulting-Hutch of Beastlineſſe, that ſwolne Parcell of Dropsies, that huge Bombard of Sacke, that ſtuft Cloake-bagge of Guts, that rosted Manning Tree Oxe with the Pudding in his Belly, that reuerend Vice, that grey ini-quitie, that Father Ruffian, that Vanitie in yeeres? where-in is he good, but to taste Sacke, and drinke it? wherein neat and cleanly, but to carue a Capon, and eat it? where-in Cunning, but in Craft? wherein Craftie, but in Villa-nie? wherein Villanous, but in all things? wherein wor-thy, but in nothing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: I would your Grace would take me with you: whom meanes your Grace?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: That villanous abhominable mis-leader of
Youth, Falstaffe, that old white-bearded Sathan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, the man I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: I know thou do'st.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: But to ſay, I know more harme in him then in my ſelfe, were to ſay more then I know. That hee is olde (the more the pittie) his white hayres doe witneſſe it: but that hee is (sauing your reuerence) a Whore-ma-ster, that I vtterly deny. If Sacke and Sugar bee a fault, Heauen helpe the Wicked: if to be olde and merry, be a ſinne, then many an olde Hoste that I know, is damn’d: if to be fat, be to be hated, then Pharaohs leane Kine are to be loued. No, my good Lord, banish Peto, banish Bardolph, banish Poines: but for ſweete Iacke Falstaffe, kinde Iacke Falstaffe, true Iacke Falstaffe, valiant Iacke Fal-staffe, and therefore more valiant, being as hee is olde Iack Falstaffe, banish not him thy Harryes companie, banish not him thy Harryes companie; banish plumpe Iacke, and banish all the World.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bard.
SPEECH.LINE: O, my Lord, my Lord, the Sherife, with a mo’t monstrous Watch, is at the doore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Out you Rogue, play out the Play: I haue much to ſay in the behalfe of that Falstaffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hosteſſe.
SPEECH.LINE: O, my Lord, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Heigh, heigh, the Deuill rides vpon a Fiddle-sticke: what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hosteſſe.
SPEECH.LINE: The Sherife and all the Watch are at the doore: they are come to ſearch the House, ſhall I let them in?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Do'st thou heare Hal, neuer call a true peece of Gold a Counterfeit: thou art eſſentially made, without ſeeming ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: And thou a naturall Coward, without in-stinct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: I deny your Maior: if you will deny the Sherife, ſo: if not, let him enter. If I become not a Cart as well as another man, a plague on my bringing vp: I hope I ſhall as ſoone be ſtrangled with a Halter, as ano-ther. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe hide thee behinde the Arras, the rest walke vp aboue. Now my Masters, for a true Face and good Conscience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Both which I haue had: but their date is out, and therefore Ile hide me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Call in the Sherife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Master Sherife, what is your will with mee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: She.
SPEECH.LINE: First pardon me, my Lord. A Hue and Cry hath followed certaine men vnto this house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: What men?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: She.
SPEECH.LINE: One of them is well knowne, my gracious Lord, a groſſe fat man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Car.
SPEECH.LINE: As fat as Butter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: The man, I doe aſſure you, is not heere,
For I my ſelfe at this time haue imploy’d him:
And Sherife, I will engage my word to thee,
That I will by to morrow Dinner time,
Send him to answere thee, or any man,
For any thing he ſhall be charg’d withall:
And ſo let me entreat you, leaue the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: She.
SPEECH.LINE: I will, my Lord: there are two Gentlemen
Haue in this Robberie lost three hundred Markes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: It may be ſo: if he haue robb’d these men,
He ſhall be answerable: and ſo farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: She.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Night, my Noble Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke it is good Morrow, is it not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: She.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeede, my Lord, I thinke it be two a Clocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: This oyly Rascall is knowne as well as Poules: goe call him forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peto.
SPEECH.LINE: Falstaffe? fast asleepe behinde the Arras, and ſnorting like a Horse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Harke, how hard he fetches breath: ſearch his Pockets. He ſearcheth his Pockets, and findeth certaine Papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: What hast thou found?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peto.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but Papers, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's ſee, what be they? reade them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peto.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, a Capon. ii.s.ii.d.
Item, Sawce iiii.d.
Item, Sacke, two Gallons. v.s.viii.d.
Item, Anchoues and Sacke after Supper. ii.s.vi.d.
Item, Bread. ob.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prince.
SPEECH.LINE: O monstrous, but one halfe penny-worth of Bread to this intollerable deale of Sacke? What there is else, keepe close, wee'le reade it at more aduantage: there let him ſleepe till day. Ile to the Court in the Morning: Wee must all to the Warres, and thy place ſhall be hono-rable. Ile procure this fat Rogue a Charge of Foot, and I know his death will be a Match of Twelue-score. The Money ſhall be pay’d backe againe with aduantage. Be with me betimes in the Morning: and ſo good mor-row Peto.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peto.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow, good my Lord.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Hotspurre, Worcester, Lord Mortimer, Owen Glendower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mort.
SPEECH.LINE: These promises are faire, the parties ſure,
And our induction full of prosperous hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hotsp.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Mortimer, and Cousin Glendower,
Will you ſit downe?
And Vnckle Worcester; a plague vpon it,
I haue forgot the Mappe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glend.
SPEECH.LINE: No, here it is:
Sit Cousin Percy, ſit good Cousin Hotspurre:
For by that Name, as oft as Lancaster doth ſpeake of you,
His Cheekes looke pale, and with a rising ſigh,
He wisheth you in Heauen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hotsp.
SPEECH.LINE: And you in Hell, as oft as he heares Owen Glen-dower ſpoke of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glend.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot blame him: At my Natiuitie,
The front of Heauen was full of fierie ſhapes,
Of burning Creſſets: and at my Birth,
The frame and foundation of the Earth
Shak’d like a Coward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hotsp.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſo it would haue done at the ſame ſeason, if your Mothers Cat had but kitten’d, though your ſelfe had neuer beene borne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glend.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay the Earth did ſhake when I was borne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hotsp.
SPEECH.LINE: And I ſay the Earth was not of my minde,
